qas.question: What type of data compression is the converse of lossless date data compression?

answers.text: Dropping nonessential detail from the data source

qas.question: What helps by eliminating off nonessential bits of information?
What type of data compression is the converse of subtle variations?
What helps by eliminating off nonessential bits of perceptual differences?
What is more sensitive to reducing size in luminance than variations in color?

plausible_answers.text: how people perceive the data in question

qas.question: What are Lossy data compression music files designed by?
What is there a corresponding compression scheme between?

context: <a0_0><b3_0>Lossy<b3_0/><a0_0/> data compression is the converse of lossless data compression. In these schemes, some loss of information is acceptable. <a1_0>Dropping nonessential detail from the data source<a1_0/> can save storage space. Lossy data compression schemes are designed by research on <b6_0>how people perceive the data in question<b6_0/>. For example, <b5_0>the human eye<b5_0/> is more sensitive to subtle variations in luminance than it is to the variations in color. <a2_0><b4_0>JPEG image compression<b4_0/><a2_0/> works in part by rounding off nonessential bits of information. There is a corresponding trade-off between <b7_0>preserving information and reducing size<b7_0/>. A number of popular compression formats exploit these perceptual differences, including those used in music files, images, and video.
